reviewText:
Watchmen Part 1 was repetitive, but had a decent enough storyline and combat to justify playing for Watchmen fans. Part 2 has the same basic Beat-Em-Up gameplay, but manages to be more repetitive and overall worse. Just like in Part 1, the storyline itself is actually a strong point. It's a separate storyline from part 1, and shows a possible explanation for why Rorschach and Nite Owl Split. It touches upon some interesting themes such as the difference between what is legal and what is ethical, and has an interesting gameplay twist at the very end, so the plotline is decent.

What isn't so good is the gameplay. In part 1, you could unlock new moves, which kept the gameplay from getting completely stale. In part 2, you start off with all of the moves from part 1 unlocked, which makes sense, but you don't unlock anything more. You end the game with the same skills you started with, meaning there is no progression and the difficulty curve is more of a difficulty flatline. Furthermore, part 2 is the same length as part one (about three hours), but has half as many levels (a total of 3), meaning you're stuck in the same area for twice as long and fighting the same enemies for twice as long (and just like part 1, there's really only two or three enemy types, just having different models on each level). The effect that all of this has is that every fight in the game is essentially identical, and since the game is almost nonstop fighting, you're going to have a bland time. Furthermore, the final level is just annoying, as it consists of you chasing the villain through a mansion. Everytime you catch up to said villain, she says something essentially boiling down to HAHA YOU'LL NEVER CATCH ME WATCHMEN" and then runs off to another room. This repeats several times in a row and just felt like a lame way to keep you moving through the level.

Overall
recommended: even though the story is decent."

reviewText:
Ok this one is shorter than the first part but it still shines a bit as it does one thing and does that one thing well.
First, do not buy this unless you can get it for 1-2 bucks.
Second, I have no idea why but I had to sit and play both games through to the end despite the repetitive gameplay and dated graphics.

It has the same strengths and weaknesses of the first one except this one inexplicably has a tutorial.

Same controller bug too. Other than that, if you like Final Fight, Double Dragon, and games of that sort, you will find this a decent button mashing brawler. The theme is a bit more adult than the last one and seeing Rorschach's brutal moves used against the female baddies...well, it was brutal, lol.

Here is my review for the first one. Like I said, pick it up on sale and you get a decent brawler that tries hard and manages to miss the mark yet is still strangely fun.

reviewText:
Watchmen: The End is Nigh Part 2 is the sequel to the horrible first game, but will the sequel fix the first ones mistakes ?

Watchmen: The End is Nigh Part 2 takes place right after the events of The End is Nigh. Rorschach get's a video film a girl so he and Nite Owl team up to get her back from her captives.

Gameplay wise the game is the same thing as part 1, nothing is changed. There's nothing new to change up the gameplay.

Graphics are the same. Very bad textures and nice comic style cut scenes. The levels do look nicer this time since they added more colors to the game.

Audio design is still as bad, the games audio cuts out and only comes back a few moments later, and the soundtrack is reused from the first part.

The game is way harder than the first part. They added new female enemies and they spam attacks that take away your health incredibly fast and the checkpoint system is messed up, the checkpoints are very far between which means dying is not an option. So your best chance of survival is to let the AI partner go in the battle head first while he takes out everyone and you just run around trying to avoid taking damage.

Level design this time is abysmal. The final level by itself is a confusing mess, really sloppy level design and everything pretty much looks the same.

Game is even shorter than part 1, only three chapters. all about 30 minutes long except for the final chapter which is about 45 minutes long. This is a tip for people who will have to play this game later on. Complete the level before exiting the game cause when you quit and return it's back to the start of the chapter. You can also play through the game twice trying out different characters. SPOILERS BEYOND THIS POINT. There is a battle between two main characters giving the game two different outcomes.

The game is also not buggy, apart from a few texture pop ins and character models spazing out and not to mention the  incredibly stupid partner AI.

The game is even worse than Part 1, This is not worth your time or money. Skip this no matter what. There is nothing good about part 2, awful level design, garbage combat and insane difficulty spike at the final chapter. Not worth the money. I give Watchmen: The End is Nigh Part 2 a 2/10

reviewText:
After disappointments from Part 1 (I gave a negative review to) it was awhile before I decided to start up #2 which might have been a mistake.  The follow up certainly makes up for what Watchmen fans were expecting out of the package.

Where as Part 1 hardly connected to anything Watchmen related (Before Watchmen, or the original Watchmen graphic novel,) and could be skipped,  Part 2 features a lot more fan service.  Surprisingly we learn a lot about the nature of Rorschach and Nite Owl's relationship not yet explored in any other Watchmen media, uncovering what led to their long hiatus as partners.

Part 2 is tied in just before some flashback events in the original comic.  [Part 1 takes place 1973.  Comedian is murdered Oct 12, 1985 (Watchmen starts).  The Keene Act is signed August 3, 1977 (flashbacks of riots). January or February 1977 Part 2 begins ending just as Keene Act is signed.]

Surprisingly the game fits perfectly into the story line.  Before Watchmen came out 3 years after the game yet it offers a great resolution to the Nite Owl's comics (which followed a 15 yaer old Nite Owl II) while leading right into the main story.

reviewText:
If I just copied and pasted my review of Part 1 onto here, all criticism would still apply. This second installment of Watchmen plays, without exaggeration, exactly like its predecessor.

The stylish combat I enjoyed so much in the first game returns but tires quick. Right from the get-go, every attack is unlocked. Consequently, you'll find yourself settling on one combo for the rest of this two hour game. There's no sense of character progression as present before.

New" enemies feel identical to the old ones but with a makeover. The new settings look nice

reviewText:
Oh jeez, where to start. I really enjoyed the first Watchmen game, and I went so far as to recommend to anyone who enjoys punching things at all. (And let's face it, most people enjoy punching things) The sequel is... a problem. The biggest issue here is that the game design left the building. The original End is Nigh ended when the game got done exploring its design. I would expect the sequel to add new elements, such as more combos, different enemy types... no, it did not. It's the first game, repackaged into new environments with three times as many physics objects.

So the gameplay is a let down, let's talk story. The original End is Nigh had a noir-esque narrative centered around the watergate scandal, and this one tells a more personal conflict. The city is up in flames due to a police strike, and in the midst of it all, Rorschach is most concenred with the well-being of a kidnapped girl, who was forced to star in underage pornography. Now, Rorschach has a problem with sexuality. A big problem. He seems to outright hate sex and anything sexy, probably due to his previous experiences.

His crusade to find and rescue the girl is justified only by the fact that she's underage, and Rorschach and a reluctant Nite Owl tear their way through a strip club and a brothel to get to her. Then, as it turns out, the kidnapped" girl wasn't underage at all
date: and was instead there of her own volition. Nite Owl attempts to tell Rorschach that there's simply nothing they can do
hoursPlayed: he isn't having that. This culminates in a battle between the two of them on the rooftop
voteText: which ultimately ends their partnership.\n\nIt's actually a pretty neat story that dives deeper into both of their characters and motivations. You always get the impression that the two are an explosive mixture
helpfulPercent: and the way they do eventually break apart is realistic and interesting.\n\nAs an animated short film
votesHelpful: this game's narrative would've been a blast
votesTotal: but one has to suffer through atrociously boring and uninspired gameplay to even get to the good parts
votesFunny: which are around 5 minutes total of the two hour experience."

reviewText: Even though this is called Part 2
date:
it really has nothing to do with the first one at all. This was somewhat confusing since part 1 left you on a cliffhanger.

This game is not nearly as good as part 1. It is even shorter, having only 3 chapters, but this time they are much longer, but also very, very repetitive. All you seem to do is beat on a bunch of guys, then the reinforcements that come after you beat them, then open an annoying door that requires both characters and takes too long to open.
Then you do it over again...and over...and over...This is tolerable for the first two chapters, but the third chapter just seems to drag on for an unnecessarily  long time. Part 1 seemed to do a much better job at fleshing everything out.
The story is not at all interesting, if you can call it a story at all. But what would you expect from a 2 hour game I guess?
I would say to anyone looking to buy this, stick with Part 1; this isn't even worth the money.
